summary.p: Regrets that he bothers Bullinger so often, but it is not about private matters, rather a public issue, namely the truth of Christ. Has heard almost nothing about the writing of the [Zürich] council; he only knows that it was somewhat welcome and has infused new strength in many to avoid the dispute - the actual goal of the writing -; he also notices how the dispute has decreased from the pulpit. The [Bernese] court clerk [Hans von Rütte] requests a large-format German Bible; Bullinger should send it through the same messenger; the money should arrive by Lucia's Day [on December 13]. Wishes Bullinger all the best in the renewed dispute with [Johannes Cochläus]. Bullinger should preserve his strength for the confrontation with Luther; he must be approached modestly, but with solid scriptural evidence, in such a way that in the zeal for the truth every mask is unveiled and nothing [false] is spared. Rümlang should also not be spared by Bullinger; he is ready to endure everything together with him and [the people of Zürich] and wants to fight fearlessly for the truth; he is and remains a Zürcher. Bullinger should recommend him to the mayor [Hans Rudolf] Lavater and all [others]; will write Bullinger any news.

div.p: Grace and peace from God, etc.

Most learned and excellent Bullinger, it pains me not a little that I must so often be a bother to you and interrupt your more serious affairs. However, it is not a private matter, but a public issue and the truth of our Lord Christ that is at stake; which requires these exchanges of letters, etc.

I have heard almost nothing about the writing of your council. It is still kept in utmost silence. I have only understood this: It was not entirely unwelcome; it has encouraged many and therefore compels to avoid disputes and disturbances; so that this matter may be expedited. But I have understood and inferred enough from the words of some: The arrogance and ferocity of the preachers, who foster dissensions, have subsided, etc.

The scribe of our judicial court requests a large-format German Bible; send it through the bearer of this letter; he will send the money by Lucia's fair. He did not dare entrust it to this boy, lest it be lost, etc.
As you once again wrestle with the foolish lawyer, I pray for success for you and for all of us.

I also wish for your strength to be preserved for Luther, with whom you must contend in utmost modesty, yet with robust scriptural testimonies, in such a way that every mask is uncovered and nothing is spared in the zeal for truth.

As for me, do not spare me in any way, nor spare my name. I am prepared to endure even the worst, if God wills it, together with you and all of you. Therefore, I pray that you deem me worthy to be included in your list. Here, I will fearlessly defend and protect the truth with all my strength, which God will supply, if only the opportunity arises, so that I may not seem to have acted beyond duty. Although the cause of truth does not always exclude importunity, I strive for this one thing, to gather and build up and not to scatter or destroy. I am and will remain a Zürcher. And I am delighted if I must engage with the pretentious and vain talkers and triflers.

Farewell. Commend me to all the learned, to the mayor Lavater, and to all. My spirit foresees all good things; for I also find that the leaders, whom I once felt were hostile to me, are now more gentle. Farewell. Whatever happens, I will write to you. Farewell.
Written hastily, on Thursday after the feast of Martin in the year 1544. Yours, Eberhard von Rümlang.
To the most upright, learned, and faithful man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, chief pastor of Zürich, his ever-observant friend and patron. To Master Heinrich Bullinger in Zürich.
